=== Crime === According to FactCheck.org, "there is no evidence that DACA holders are more likely to commit crimes than U.S. citizens." Factcheck.Org noted that "numerous studies have found that immigrants do not commit crimes at a higher rate than non-immigrants."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.factcheck.org/2017/02/no-evidence-sanctuary-cities-breed-crime/|title=No Evidence Sanctuary Cities 'Breed Crime' |date=2017-02-10|work=FactCheck.org|access-date=2018-01-10|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Economy === Fact-checkers note that, on a large scale or in the long run, there is no reason to believe that DACA recipients have a major deleterious effect on American workers' employment chances; to the contrary, some economists say that DACA benefits the overall U.S. economy.<ref name=":11" /><ref name=":9"/><ref name=":12" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.politifact.com/new-york/statements/2017/sep/10/louise-slaughter/would-trumps-decision-daca-hurt-new-yorks-economy/|title=What's the economic impact of ending DACA?|work=@politifact|access-date=2017-09-17|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":15">{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/2017/09/08/dacas-end-would-hurt-economy-hiring/638835001/|title=DACA's end would hurt economy, hiring|work=USA Today|access-date=2017-09-17|language=en}}</ref> Economists have warned that ending DACA could adversely affect the U.S. economy, and that "most economists see immigration generally as an ''economic boon''."<ref name=":12" /><ref name=":15" /> Almost all economists reject [[Jeff Sessions]]' claim that DACA "denied jobs to hundreds of thousands of Americans by allowing those same jobs to go to illegal aliens."<ref name=":12" /> Sessions' claim is rooted in what economists call the "[[Lump of labour fallacy|lump of labor fallacy]]" (i.e., the idea that there is a limit to amount of work force available in any economy).<ref name=":11" /><ref>{{Cite web|author=Tracy Jan|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2017/09/06/white-house-claims-dreamers-take-jobs-away-from-blacks-and-hispanics-heres-the-truth/|title=Analysis: White House claims 'dreamers' take jobs away from blacks and Hispanics. Here's the truth.|website=Washington Post|date=September 6, 2017}}</ref>
A 2016 study in the ''[[Journal of Public Economics]]'' found that DACA increased [[labor force participation]] and decreased the unemployment rate for DACA-eligible immigrants. DACA also increased the income of illegal immigrants in the bottom of the income distribution.<ref name=":3" /> The study estimates that DACA moved 50,000 to 75,000 unauthorized immigrants into employment.<ref name=":3" /> According to [[University of California, Davis]] economist [[Giovanni Peri]], DACA consequently "increases consumption and overall demand for U.S. services, products, and jobs where the DACA recipients live and spend. Economists have shown that highly skilled workers increase local productivity and create opportunities for the other workers too".<ref name=":14">{{Cite news|url=http://econofact.org/the-economic-cost-of-repealing-daca|title=The Economic Cost of Repealing DACA {{!}} Econofact|date=2017-09-11|work=Econofact|access-date=2017-09-13|language=en-US}}</ref> A 2016 study in ''[[Economics Letters]]'' found that DACA-eligible households were 38% less likely than non-eligible unauthorized immigrant households to live in poverty.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Amuedo-Dorantes|first=Catalina|last2=Antman|first2=Francisca|title=Can authorization reduce poverty among undocumented immigrants? Evidence from the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program|journal=Economics Letters|volume=147|pages=1–4|doi=10.1016/j.econlet.2016.08.001|year=2016|hdl=10419/145279}}</ref> Furthermore, DACA-eligible workers tend to have higher-skilled, higher-paying jobs than undocumented immigrants.<ref name="gould-and-garfield-2017">{{cite news |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-daca-and-how-much-will-it-cost-the-us-2017-9 |title=How much money a DACA repeal could cost every state |first1=Skye |last1=Gould |first2=Leanna |last2=Garfield |newspaper=[[Business Insider]] |date=September 6, 2017 }}</ref>
According to one survey, 91 percent of DACA registrants are employed, and 5 percent have launched their own businesses, compared to 3.1 percent of all Americans.<ref name="Davidson">{{cite news|url=https://www.pressreader.com/usa/usa-today-us-edition/20170908/281814284019119|title=Analysts Say Ending DACA would Hurt Economy, Hiring|last=Davidson|first=Paul|date=September 8, 2017|work=USA Today|publisher=PressReader|accessdate=9 March 2018}}</ref> According to [[Giovanni Peri]], ending DACA would bring a net loss in [[Productivity (economics)|productivity]], given that, {{as of|2017|lc=y}}, the U.S. economy is close to [[full employment]].<ref name=":11" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/0/daca-dreamers/|title=What is Daca and who are the Dreamers?|work=The Telegraph|access-date=September 6, 2017|language=en-GB}}</ref> Ike Brannon and Logan Albright of the [[CATO Institute]] wrote in a 2017 that ending DACA would have an adverse economic and fiscal impact, estimating that the cost of immediately eliminating DACA and deporting those who received deferred action would be $283 billion over a decade (representing an economic loss of $215 billion, a fiscal loss of $60 billion (from lower net tax revenue), and $7.5 billion in deportation costs).<ref name="Cato">{{Cite news|author=Ike Brannon and Logan Albright|url=https://www.cato.org/blog/economic-fiscal-impact-repealing-daca|title=The Economic and Fiscal Impact of Repealing DACA|publisher=Cato Institute|date=January 18, 2017|language=en}}</ref> Brannon and Albright wrote that their projections were "a conservative estimate due to the fact that many DACA immigrants are young and still acquiring education credentials that will boost wages later."<ref name="Cato"/> The Immigrant Legal Resource Center estimated that deporting DACA-eligible individuals would reduce Social Security and Medicare tax revenue by $24.6 billion over a decade.<ref name=":12" /> Peri argues that DACA recipients likely have a significant net positive fiscal impact given that DACA-eligible individuals have similar characteristics as second-generation immigrants, and that research shows that second-generation immigrants have a net positive fiscal impact of $173,000 to $259,000 per immigrant.<ref name=":14" /> Peri also notes that the U.S. public school system has already invested in educating these individuals, and they are at the point at which they can start contributing to the U.S. economy and public coffers; deporting them or increasing the likelihood that they be deported is economically counterproductive.<ref name=":14" /> A 2017 study by the [[Center for American Progress]] estimated that the loss of all DACA-eligible workers would reduce U.S. [[GDP]] by $433 billion over the next 10 years.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/09/05/daca-deportations-could-cost-us-economy-more-than-400-billion.html|title=DACA deportations could cost US economy more than $400 billion|last=Schoen|first=John W.|date=September 5, 2017|access-date=September 6, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Silva Mathema|url=https://www.americanprogress.org/issues/immigration/news/2017/01/09/296125/ending-daca-will-cost-states-billions-of-dollars/|title=Ending DACA Will Cost States Billions of Dollars|publisher=Center for American Progress|date=January 9, 2017}}</ref>
According to Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas economist Pia Orrenius, due to their risk of deportation, it is likely that previously DACA-protected individuals would slip into the shadow economy or take low-profile jobs that pay less.<ref name=":15" />
A 2018 National Bureau of Economic Research paper found that DACA likely led to greater productivity by increasing the college attendance and employment of DACA-eligible individuals.<ref name=":17">{{Cite journal|last=Kuka|first=Elira|last2=Shenhav|first2=Na'ama|last3=Shih|first3=Kevin|date=February 2018|title=Do Human Capital Decisions Respond to the Returns to Education? Evidence from DACA|journal=NBER Working Paper No. 24315 |doi=10.3386/w24315 }}</ref>
=== Education === Research has shown mixed findings for DACA on education outcomes. A 2016 study in the ''Journal of Public Economics'' found that DACA had no significant effect on the likelihood of attending school.<ref name=":3" /> The study only found "suggestive evidence that DACA pushed over 25,000 DACA-eligible individuals into obtaining their GED certificate in order to be eligible for DACA."<ref name=":3" /> However, research by Roberto G. Gonzales, professor of education at Harvard University, showed that DACA led to increased educational attainment.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vox.com/2017/9/2/16244380/daca-benefits-trump-undocumented-immigrants-jobs|title=DACA's beneficiaries landed good jobs, enrolled in college, and contributed to society|work=Vox|access-date=2017-09-17}}</ref> A 2018 [[National Bureau of Economic Research]] paper found that DACA led to greater high school attainment and college attendance for DACA-eligible individuals.<ref name=":17" />
A 2016 study in the ''[[Journal of Population Economics]]'' found that DACA "reduced the probability of school enrollment of eligible higher-educated individuals, as well as some evidence that it increased the employment likelihood of men, in particular. Together, these findings suggest that a lack of authorization may lead individuals to enroll in school when working is not a viable option."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Amuedo-Dorantes|first=Catalina|last2=Antman|first2=Francisca|date=2017-01-01|title=Schooling and labor market effects of temporary authorization: evidence from DACA|journal=Journal of Population Economics|language=en|volume=30|issue=1|pages=339–73|doi=10.1007/s00148-016-0606-z|pmid=28690364|pmc=5497855|issn=0933-1433}}</ref>
The effects of the rescinding and subsequent reimplementation of DACA has affected college students dramatically. The primary effects are psychological and educational in nature. The first way it does so is the general stress that comes along with having an uncertain legal status, in fact 70.9% of DACA recipients strongly agree that they worry about the future of the program<ref name=":02">Enriquez, Laura E., et al. "Deconstructing Immigrant Illegality: A Mixed-Methods Investigation of Stress and Health Among Undocumented College Students." ''Race & Social Problems'', vol. 10, no. 3, Sept. 2018, p. 193. {{doi|10.1007/s12552-018-9242-4}}.</ref>. Many recipients have spoken about how their DACA status gives them anxiety because of fear for the unknown<ref name=":02" />. This can then affect their education because individuals take that uncertainty and apply it to how much effort they should be putting into their school work. Thus, without knowing if they will be deported at any moment many DACA students reduce the amount of time they spend doing coursework, and some even drop out in favor of earning money at a job. A recent study shows the compound effect of being at a four-year university vs. a community college with 7.3% increase in dropout rates<ref>Hsin, Amy and Francesc Ortega. “The Effects of Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals on the Educational Outcomes of Undocumented Students.” ''Demography'', vol. 55, no. 4, Aug. 2018, pp. 1487–1506. ''EBSCOhost'', {{doi|10.1007/s13524-018-0691-6}}.</ref>. Not only does this status make individuals less likely to finish their undergraduate degree, but it can even stop students from pursuing a graduate degree, especially in terms of funding<ref>Muñoz, Susana M., and Darsella Vigil. “Interrogating Racist Nativist Microaggressions and Campus Climate: How Undocumented and DACA College Students Experience Institutional Legal Violence in Colorado.” ''Journal of Diversity in Higher Education'', May 2018. ''EBSCOhost'', {{doi|10.1037/dhe0000078}}.</ref>.
The psychological effects of this status also becomes a barrier for DACA students in their college experience, largely because of the uncertainty that the status carries. Many reported high rates of extreme stress and anxiety as compared to their documented counterparts<ref name=":02" />. Also, the internalizing of the label "illegal" made it so that these individuals saw themselves as less human. In certain cases this meant more instances of self-harm and even suicide in some cases<ref>Gonzales, R. G. "No Place to Belong: Contextualizing Concepts of Mental Health among Undocumented Immigrant Youth in the United States." ''American behavioral scientist (Beverly Hills)'' 57.8 (2013): 1174-99. Web.</ref>.
=== Health === A 2017 study published in the journal ''[[Science (journal)|Science]]'' found that DACA led to improved mental health outcomes for the children of DACA-eligible mothers.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Hainmueller|first=Jens|last2=Lawrence|first2=Duncan|last3=Martén|first3=Linna|last4=Black|first4=Bernard|last5=Figueroa|first5=Lucila|last6=Hotard|first6=Michael|last7=Jiménez|first7=Tomás R.|last8=Mendoza|first8=Fernando|last9=Rodriguez|first9=Maria I.|date=August 31, 2017|title=Protecting unauthorized immigrant mothers improves their children's mental health|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/early/2017/08/30/science.aan5893|journal=Science|volume=357|issue=6355|language=en|pages=1041–44|doi=10.1126/science.aan5893|issn=0036-8075|pmid=28860206|pmc=5990252|bibcode=2017Sci...357.1041H}}</ref> A 2017 [[The Lancet|''Lancet Public Health'']] study found that DACA-eligible individuals had better mental health outcomes as a result of their DACA eligibility.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Venkataramani|first=Atheendar S|last2=Shah|first2=Sachin J|last3=O'Brien|first3=Rourke|last4=Kawachi|first4=Ichiro|last5=Tsai|first5=Alexander C|title=Health consequences of the US Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) immigration programme: a quasi-experimental study|journal=The Lancet Public Health|volume=2|issue=4|pages=e175–81|doi=10.1016/s2468-2667(17)30047-6|pmid=29253449|year=2017}}</ref> A 2018 study in the journal ''[[Social Science & Medicine|Social Sciences & Medicine]]'' found that DACA-eligible individuals who transitioned from illegal to legal status had improved psychological wellbeing.<ref name=":13" />
''[[FiveThirtyEight]]'', summarizing the findings of past research, wrote that "the threat of deportation alone would likely have a negative impact on families. Immigration-related stress and anxiety have been shown to have negative health effects... Generally, researchers believe the stress that stems from the fear of having a parent deported has far-reaching, negative effects on the health of children."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-end-of-daca-will-ripple-through-families-and-communities|title=The End Of DACA Will Ripple Through Families And Communities|last=Barry-Jester|first=Anna Maria|date=2017-09-06|work=FiveThirtyEight|access-date=2017-09-08|language=en-US}}</ref> In an editorial for the ''[[The New England Journal of Medicine|New England Journal of Medicine]]'', Atheendar S. Venkataramani, professor of medicine at the University of Pennsylvania, and Alexander C. Tsai, professor of psychiatry at Harvard Medical School, wrote, "The evidence clearly indicates that rescinding DACA will have profound adverse population-level effects on mental health... DACA was never intended to be a public health program, but its population-level consequences for mental health have been significant and rival those of any large-scale health or social policies in recent history. Rescinding DACA therefore represents a threat to public mental health."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Venkataramani|first=Atheendar S.|last2=Tsai|first2=Alexander C.|date=2017-09-13|title=Dreams Deferred – The Public Health Consequences of Rescinding DACA|journal=New England Journal of Medicine|volume=0|issue=18|pages=1707–09|doi=10.1056/NEJMp1711416|issn=0028-4793|pmid=28902574}}</ref>
21 percent of DACA-protected immigrants work in education and health services.<ref name=":15" /> The American Medical Association has estimated that under DACA or similar legislation, 5,400 additional physicians would work in the United States in coming decades, alleviating a projected shortage of primary care physicians.<ref name=":15" />
=== Migration flows === A 2016 study published in the journal ''International Migration'' found that DACA did not significantly impact the number of apprehensions of unaccompanied minors from Central America.<ref name=":23">{{Cite journal|last=Amuedo-Dorantes|first=Catalina|last2=Puttitanun|first2=Thitima|date=August 1, 2016|title=DACA and the Surge in Unaccompanied Minors at the US–Mexico Border|journal=International Migration|language=en|volume=54|issue=4|pages=102–17|doi=10.1111/imig.12250|issn=1468-2435}}</ref> A 2015 [[Government Accountability Office]] (GAO) report assessing the reasons behind the surge in unaccompanied minors from Central America did not mention DACA, and cited crime and lack of economic opportunity as the main reasons behind the surge.<ref name=":9"/>
=== Safety and privacy === After The Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals was repealed, a concern for safety became prominent in illegal alien families. In a study from PRI's The World, Caitlin Patler,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://go.galegroup.com/ps/i.do?p=STND&u=jcl_jccc&id=GALE|A515326535&v=2.1&it=r&sid=summon|title=DACA recipients saw their mental health improve. Now, advocates fear its end will have the opposite effect|last=Patler|first=Caitlin|date=November 22, 2017|work=PRI's The World|access-date=April 19, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> assistant professor of sociology at UC Davis, says that DACA recipients have lost "ontological security." They think about the personal information they have given the government and worry that they will be deported or unable to work or study, she says. "These young people cannot count on the promise of the future." Many DACA recipients believe safety to be a prominent issue since the repeal of the act. In another journal by US Official News,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://go.galegroup.com/ps/i.do?p=STND&u=jcl_jccc&id=GALE|A503854818&v=2.1&it=r&sid=summon|title=How DACA affected the mental health of undocumented young adults|last=|first=|date=September 9, 2017|work=US Official News|access-date=April 19, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> it is revealed that "almost 800,000 youth trusted the government with their "fingerprints" and other personal information when they applied for DACA. In return, the two-year reprieve from deportation lifted the constant, everyday fear of existence that characterized their lives. These mental health gains, in addition to the fruits of all of their hard work over the past five years, are now threatened."
==Legal challenges to DACA== {{see also|United States v. Texas}} The legality of DACA and its proposed expansions were challenged in court. But only the expansions were halted under a preliminary injunction. Legal experts are divided as to the constitutionality of DACA, but no court has yet to rule it unconstitutional.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2017/sep/11/eric-schneiderman/has-daca-been-ruled-unconstitutional/|title=Have courts ruled on DACA's constitutionality?|work=@politifact|access-date=2017-09-17|language=en}}</ref>
One of challenges against DACA was filed in August 2012 by ten agents from the [[U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement]] (ICE).<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2012/08/23/159926481/immigration-employees-file-suit-against-obamas-new-immigration-policy |title=Immigration Employees File Suit Against Obama's New Immigration Policy |first=Corey |last=Dade |date=August 23, 2012 |newspaper=[[NPR]] }}</ref> The plaintiffs claimed that following the new lenient deportation policies established by DACA required them to violate the law. Almost a year later, Judge [[Reed O'Connor]] from the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas|U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas]] dismissed the lawsuit, ruling that the court lacked jurisdiction to decide on what essentially was a dispute between federal employees and their employer, the U.S. government.<ref name="llorente-fn-2012">{{cite new |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2013/08/01/judge-dismisses-immigration-agents-lawsuit-against-obama-program-to-suspend.html |title=Judge Dismisses ICE Agents' Lawsuit Challenging Obama's Deferred Action |publisher=[[Fox News]] |first=Elizabeth |last=Llorente |date=August 1, 2013 }}</ref> Nonetheless, in his decision to dismiss the case, the judge reiterated his view that DACA was inherently unlawful.<ref name="llorente-fn-2012" /> The plaintiffs then filed an appeal but the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit|U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit]] upheld the dismissal on procedural grounds.
The first challenge against the DACA expansions was filed by Sheriff [[Joe Arpaio]] of [[Maricopa County, Arizona]], in November 2014. In the lawsuit, Arpaio claimed that DACA and its expansions were "unconstitutional, arbitrary and capricious, and invalid under the [[Administrative Procedure Act (United States)|Administrative Procedure Act]] as, in effect, regulations that have been promulgated without the requisite opportunity for public notice and comment."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/volokh-conspiracy/wp/2015/08/16/sherriff-arpaio-lacks-standing-to-challenge-obama-immigration-initiatives/|title=Sheriff Arpaio lacks standing to challenge Obama immigration initiatives |first=Jonathan |last=Adler |date=August 16, 2015 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] }}</ref> The [[U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia]] promptly dismissed the lawsuit ruling that Arpaio did not have [[standing (law)|standing]]. That decision was upheld unanimously by the [[U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit]] on August 14, 2015. Arpaio then asked the U.S. Supreme Court to review the case, but on January 19, 2016, the court denied that request.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.americanimmigrationcouncil.org/research/legal-challenges-executive-action-on-immigration |title=Understanding the Legal Challenges to Executive Action |publisher=[[American Immigration Council]] |date=June 28, 2016 }}</ref>
The challenge that was granted a preliminary injunction was filed on December 2014 by Texas and 25 other states—all with Republican governors. The group of states [[lawsuit|sued]] to enjoin the implementation of the [[Deferred Action for Parents of Americans]] (DAPA)—another immigration policy—and the DACA expansions announced by the Obama administration.<ref>{{cite web|last=Zargham|first=Mohammad|title=Obama's immigration action blocked again; Supreme Court only option left|agency=[[Reuters]]|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/11/10/us-usa-immigration-court-idUSKCN0SZ04W20151110|date=November 9, 2015|accessdate=November 9, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/04/us/executive-action-on-immigration-prompts-texas-to-sue.html|title = 17 states suing on immigration|date = 3 December 2014|accessdate = 27 February 2015|newspaper = [[The New York Times]]|publisher = |authors= David Montgomery and Julia Preston}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.texasattorneygeneral.gov/files/epress/files/20141203Multi-stateImmigrationOrderLawsuit%281%29.pdf |title=Texas et. al. v. United States et. al.: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief |date=3 December 2014 |accessdate=27 February 2015 |website= |publisher=[[Texas Attorney General|Office of the Attorney General of Texas]] |last= |first= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402104146/https://www.texasattorneygeneral.gov/files/epress/files/20141203Multi-stateImmigrationOrderLawsuit%281%29.pdf |archivedate=2 April 2015 |df= }}</ref> In the lawsuit, the states claimed that, by expanding DACA, the president failed to enforce the nation's immigration laws in contravention to [[Article Two of the United States Constitution|Article Two of the U.S. Constitution]].<ref name="masters-cfr-2016">{{cite news |url=https://www.cfr.org/backgrounder/us-supreme-court-and-obamas-immigration-actions |title=The U.S. Supreme Court and Obama's Immigration Actions |first=Jonathan |last=Masters |publisher=[[Council on Foreign Relations]] |date=June 23, 2015 }}</ref>{{efn|''Texas v. United States'' (2016) "The Court has federal question jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. § 1331 because this action arises under the U.S. Constitution, art. II, § 3, cl. 5 [.]"<ref name="texas-v-us" />}} Moreover, the states claimed that the president unilaterally rewrote the law through his actions.<ref name="texas-v-us">{{cite web |title=''Texas v. United States'', No. 1:14-cv-254 (District Court for the Southern District of Texas) |url=https://www.texasattorneygeneral.gov/files/epress/files/ImmigrationStatesFirstAmendedLawsuit12092014.pdf }}</ref> As part of the judicial process, in February 2015, Judge [[Andrew S. Hanen]] issued a preliminary [[injunction]] blocking the expansion from going into effect while the case, ''[[Texas v. United States]]'', proceeded.<ref name="nytimes2">{{Citation | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/18/us/politics/republicans-say-ruling-aids-bid-in-congress-to-block-obama-on-immigration.html | newspaper = The New York Times | title = After Judge's Ruling Obama Delays Immigration Actions | date = February 18, 2015| last1 = Shear | first1 = Michael D. | last2 = Preston | first2 = Julia }}</ref><ref name="uclalawreview58">{{cite journal|last1=Kalhan|first1=Anil|title=Deferred Action, Supervised Enforcement Discretion, and the Rule of Law Basis for Executive Action on Immigration|journal=UCLA Law Review Discourse|date=2015|volume=63|page=58|url=http://www.uclalawreview.org/deferred-action-supervised-enforcement-discretion-rule-law-basis-executive-action-immigration/}}</ref> After progressing through the court system, an equally divided (4–4) [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] left the injunction in place, without setting any precedent.<ref name="NYTJune24">{{cite news|last1=Liptak|first1=Adam|last2=Shear|first2=Michael D.|title=Split Court Stifles Obama on Immigration: A 9-Word Ruling Erases a Shield for Millions|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/24/us/supreme-court-immigration-obama-dapa.html|accessdate=June 25, 2016|work=The New York Times|date=June 24, 2016|page=A1, Column 1}}</ref> The court's temporary injunction did not affect the existing DACA. At the time, individuals were allowed to continue to come forward and request an initial grant of DACA or renewal of DACA under the guidelines established in 2012.<ref name="uscis" />
Regardless of the outcome of the preliminary injunction, legal opinions on the lawfulness of DACA are divided. In ''[[United States v. Texas]]'', for instance, the Obama administration argued that the policy was a lawful exercise of the enforcement discretion that Congress delegated to the executive branch in the [[Immigration and Nationality Act]], which charges the executive with the administration and enforcement of the country's immigration laws.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.aclu.org/blog/immigrants-rights/road-citizenship/are-states-coordinating-trump-administration-take-down-daca |title=Are States Coordinating With the Trump Administration to Take Down DACA? We Aim to Find Out. |first=Michael |last=Tan |publisher=[[American Civil Liberties Union]] |date=August 7, 2017 }}</ref> Conversely, [[Jay Sekulow]], Chief Counsel of the [[American Center for Law and Justice]], opined that DACA was unlawful by asserting that it unconstitutionally usurped Congress' role over immigration by illegally allowing certain classes of illegal aliens to violate U.S. immigration law with impunity.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://aclj.org/immigration/end-of-an-error-dealing-with-daca-from-the-proper-perspective |title=End of an Error: Dealing With DACA From the Proper Perspective |first=Jay |last=Sekulow |date=September 6, 2017 |publisher=[[American Center for Law and Justice]] }}</ref>
On May 1, 2018, a coalition of 7 States, led by [[Texas]], filed a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of the program, after originally promising to challenge the program if the administration didn't rescind it.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.texastribune.org/2018/05/01/texas-and-six-other-states-sue-end-daca/|title=Texas and 6 other states sue to end DACA|last=Platoff|first=Emma|date=May 1, 2018|work=Texas Tribune|accessdate=4 August 2018}}</ref> On August 31, 2018, District Court Judge [[Andrew Hanen]] ruled that DACA is likely unconstitutional, however he let the program remain in place as litigation proceeds.<ref name=":18" /><ref name=":19" />
==State and city responses== {{missing information|section|the quantitative and qualitative differences between the states that support DACA and those that oppose it|date=September 2017}} State-level government officials are also divided on the issue. Those that support DACA claim that the government does not have the resources to target all illegal immigrants and that the policy thus helps federal agencies in exerting prosecutorial discretion—that is, [[selective enforcement|in enforcing the law selectively]] by focusing limited resources on criminal immigrants rather than on non-criminal ones such as those eligible for DACA.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/27/us/politics/dreamers-trump-lawsuit.html |title='Dreamer' Plan That Aided 800,000 Immigrants Is Threatened |first=Miriam |last=Jordan |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=August 27, 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://theweek.com/articles/723056/obamas-original-sin-daca |title=Obama's original sin on DACA |first=Edward |last=Morrissey |date=September 7, 2017 |newspaper=[[The Week]] }}</ref> Those that oppose the policy, however, claim that states would be forced to spend hundreds of millions of dollars on health care, education, law enforcement, and other public benefits associated with the immigrants receiving relief.<ref name="masters-cfr-2016" /> For instance, DACA opponents claim that Texas could assume up to $500 million in administrative costs for issuing new driver's licenses.<ref name="masters-cfr-2016" />
===Arizona===
Arizona became the first state to oppose President Obama's order for DACA when Governor [[Jan Brewer]] issued an order blocking those with deferred status from receiving any state benefits.<ref>{{cite news|last=Schwartz|first=David|title=Jan Brewer Signs Executive Order Denying State Benefits to Children of illegal immigrants|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/08/15/jan-brewer-executive-order_n_1785482.html|accessdate=October 12, 2012|newspaper=Huffington Post|date=August 15, 2012}}</ref> This caused controversy,<ref>{{cite news|last=Shoichet|first=Catherine E.|title=Driver's license rules fuel new immigration debate|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/08/21/us/states-immigration-policy/index.html|publisher=CNN|accessdate=October 12, 2012}}</ref> as eligible and approved applicants would still be unable to obtain a driver's license.<ref>{{cite news|last=Eng|first=James|title=Arizona Gov. Jan Brewer's ban on driver's licenses for illegal immigrants likely to wind up in court|url=http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/08/16/13317418-arizona-gov-jan-brewers-ban-on-drivers-licenses-for-illegal-immigrants-likely-to-wind-up-in-court|accessdate=October 12, 2012|newspaper=NBC News}}</ref> In May 2013, a federal district court held that this policy was likely unconstitutional. In 2014, the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit|U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit]] issued a preliminary injunction against Brewer's ban, and in November 2014 held this ban was in violation of the law.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acluaz.org/issues/press-releases/2014-11/4968|title=Decision – at long last – paves the way for young immigrants to apply for driver's licenses|last=|first=|date=November 24, 2014|website=|publisher=ACLU of Arizona|access-date=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141127222356/http://www.acluaz.org/issues/press-releases/2014-11/4968#|archive-date=2014-11-27|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
===California===
To assist those eligible under the program,<ref>{{cite news|title=California lawmakers seek relief for illegal immigrants to work in state|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/california-politics/2012/08/california-lawmakers-illegal-immigrants.html|accessdate=October 12, 2012|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=August 23, 2012}}</ref> the state of California has agreed to support those who receive a DACA grant by allowing access to a state driver's license,<ref>{{cite news|title=California will give driver's licenses to illegal immigrants|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2012/10/california-will-give-drivers-licenses-to-illegal-immigrants-video-discussion.html|accessdate=October 12, 2012|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=October 1, 2012}}</ref> provided that such individuals participate in specific state guidelines (such as paying [[income taxes]]). The state of California also allows DACA holding individuals to qualify for [[Medi-Cal]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brindis|first=Claire|year=2014|title=Realizing the Dream for Californians Eligible for Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA): Demographics and Health Coverage.|url=http://laborcenter.berkeley.edu/pdf/2014/DACA_health_coverage.pdf|publisher=UCLA Center for Health Policy Research|volume=|pages=|via=EBSCOhost}}</ref>
===Illinois===
[[Mayor of Chicago]] [[Rahm Emanuel]] stated that he wants to make [[Demographics of Chicago|Chicago]] the "most immigrant-friendly city in the country".<ref name="most friendly" /> In addition to offering in-state tuition for illegal immigrants, he has also made plans for a city ordinance that would prevent illegal immigrants with no criminal background from being turned over to immigration enforcement agencies.<ref name="most friendly">{{cite news|last=Preston|first=Julia|title=Obama Policy on Immigrants Is Challenged by Chicago|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/11/us/obama-policy-on-illegal-immigrants-is-challenged-by-chicago.html|accessdate=October 12, 2012|newspaper=New York Times|date=July 10, 2012}}</ref>
===Iowa===
In 2012, the then-director of the Iowa Department of Transportation, [[Paul Trombino III]] (now nominee for Administrator of the Federal Highway Administration), announced a policy to deny driver's licenses to Iowa residents who were part of the DACA program. The policy was reversed several weeks later.<ref name="ag171008">{{cite news|title=Director of the Federal Highway Administration: Who Is Paul Trombino?|url=http://www.allgov.com/news/top-stories/director-of-the-federal-highway-administration-who-is-paul-trombino-171008?news=860327|accessdate=9 October 2017|publisher=AllGov|date=Oct 8, 2017}}</ref><ref name="usat121227">{{cite news|last1=Petroski|first1=William|title=Iowa stance on immigrant driver's licenses criticized|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2012/12/27/iowa-immigrant-drivers-licenses/1795427/|accessdate=9 October 2017|publisher=USA Today|date=December 27, 2012}}</ref>
===Maryland=== In 2016, [[List of mayors of Baltimore|Mayor of Baltimore (2010-2016)]] [[Stephanie Rawlings-Blake]] stated that [[Baltimore Police Department|Baltimore police]] would not check the citizenship status of people with whom they interact.<ref>Wenger, Yvonne. "[http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/baltimore-city/politics/bs-md-ci-welcoming-city-20161117-story.html Mayor: Baltimore is a 'welcoming city' for immigrants and refugees]". ''[[The Baltimore Sun]]''. November 17, 2016.</ref>
Maryland residents are eligible for in-state public tuition rates regardless of immigration status under certain conditions. A Maryland resident is eligible if they attended Maryland high schools for at least three of the previous twelve years and they graduated from a Maryland high school or received a Maryland [[General Educational Development|GED]] within the previous ten years. They must have registered at a Maryland public college within four years of high school graduation or receiving a Maryland GED. They must have registered for [[Selective Service]] if male, and they must have filed Maryland income tax returns.<ref>Anderson, Nick; Lazo, Luz. "[https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/md-politics/md-voters-deciding-on-dream-act-law/2012/11/06/d539fe66-282f-11e2-bab2-eda299503684_story.html Md. voters approve ‘Dream Act’ law]". ''The Washington Post''. November 7, 2012.<br />"[http://cms.montgomerycollege.edu/EDU/Department.aspx?id=53773 Maryland Dream Act: New Fall Student]". Montgomery College. Retrieved August 31, 2017.<br />"[http://cms.montgomerycollege.edu/EDU/Department.aspx?id=53780 Maryland Dream Act: New Fall 2017: I meet the requirements]". Montgomery College. Retrieved August 31, 2017.</ref>
===Michigan===
In October 2012, the Michigan Secretary of State, [[Ruth Johnson]], announced that Michigan would not issue driver's licenses or state identification of any kind to beneficiaries of Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Oosting|first1=Jonathan|title=Federal program allows some illegal immigrants to work, but they won't be able to drive in Michigan|url=http://www.mlive.com/politics/index.ssf/2012/10/federal_program_allows_some_il.html|website=mlive.com|date=October 18, 2012}}</ref> In making this decision, it was clear that the Secretary of State erroneously conflated the notion of "lawful presence," which is required under Michigan Law to issue a driver's license, and "lawful status," a different legal concept entirely.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://docs.google.com/file/d/0B1UQnwyWpg02cDFJTGdUNEVsTXc/edit?pli=1 |title=Issue-Brief-SOS-DACA-licenses.pdf – Google Drive |date= |accessdate=September 30, 2013}}</ref> USCIS has made it clear that DACA beneficiaries do not possess legal status, but does ''not'' state that DACA beneficiaries are unlawfully present; in fact, it states that DACA beneficiaries will not accrue unlawful presence time here while they are in this deferred action status.<ref name="uscis1">{{cite web|url=http://www.uscis.gov/portal/site/uscis/menuitem.eb1d4c2a3e5b9ac89243c6a7543f6d1a/?vgnextoid=f2ef2f19470f7310VgnVCM100000082ca60aRCRD&vgnextchannel=f2ef2f19470f7310VgnVCM100000082ca60aRCRD |title=Consideration of Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals Process |publisher=United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS)|date= |accessdate=September 30, 2013}}</ref> The Secretary of State relied upon USCIS' own explanation, which discusses legal status, not lawful presence.<ref name="uscis1" /> In response to this policy, the ACLU filed a lawsuit against Johnson, alleging that the policy violated both Michigan law and the U.S. Constitution.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aclu.org/immigrants-rights/one-michigan-v-ruth-johnson |title=One Michigan v. Ruth Johnson|publisher=[[American Civil Liberties Union]]|date=February 1, 2013 |accessdate=September 30, 2013}}</ref> On January 18, 2013, USCIS updated their "Frequently Asked Questions" page about DACA, clarifying, among other things, that DACA beneficiaries are, in fact, ''lawfully present'' in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uscis.gov/portal/site/uscis/menuitem.eb1d4c2a3e5b9ac89243c6a7543f6d1a/?vgnextoid=3a4dbc4b04499310VgnVCM100000082ca60aRCRD&vgnextchannel=3a4dbc4b04499310VgnVCM100000082ca60aRCRD |title=Frequently Asked Questions |publisher=Uscis.gov (USCIS)|date= |accessdate=September 30, 2013}}</ref> On February 1, 2013, Johnson reversed her policy and began issuing driver's licenses to DACA beneficiaries on February 19, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jonathan Oosting |url=http://www.mlive.com/politics/index.ssf/2013/02/michigan_secretary_of_state_to.html |title=Michigan Secretary of State to issue driver's licenses to immigrants approved for federal deportation deferral program |publisher=MLive.com |date= |accessdate=September 30, 2013}}</ref>
===Nebraska=== [[Governor of Nebraska|Governor]] [[Dave Heineman]] opposed Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals and in 2012 directed the Nebraska Department of Motor Vehicles to not issue driver's licenses to people who received deferred action under DACA. Heineman said that providing any benefit, including a driver's license, to an illegal immigrant would be a violation of Nebraska state law.<ref name="Duggan">Duggan, Joe (May 30, 2015). "[http://www.omaha.com/news/legislature/nebraska-begins-issuing-driver-s-licenses-to-children-of-illegal/article_efd9dd5e-064e-11e5-b1db-e36469ae3b08.html Nebraska begins issuing driver's licenses to children of illegal immigrants]". ''Omaha World-Herald''.</ref>
In 2015, however, the [[Nebraska Legislature]] determined that Section 202(c)(B)(viii) of the [[REAL ID Act|REAL ID Act of 2015]] required states to allow people to present documentation of deferred-action status when registering for a driver's license, and the Nebraska Legislature voted to change state law to allow qualified individuals with DACA to receive licenses by using documentation of their status of deferred action.<ref name="Duggan"/><ref>"[https://www.dhs.gov/xlibrary/assets/real-id-act-text.pdf REAL ID Act – Title II]". ''United States Congress'', via United States Department of Homeland Security. 2015.</ref><ref>"[https://nebraskalegislature.gov/FloorDocs/104/PDF/Intro/LB623.pdf Legislative Bill 623]". ''Nebraska Legislature''. Section 1. January 21, 2015. "The Legislature finds and declares that section 202(c)(2)(B)(i) through (ix) of the federal REAL ID Act of 2005, Public Law 5 109-13, enumerated categories of individuals who may demonstrate lawful status for the purpose of eligibility for a federally secure motor vehicle operator's license or state identification card. The Legislature further finds and declares that it was the intent of the Legislature in 2011 to adopt the enumerated categories by the passage of Laws 2011, LB 215. The Legislature declares that the passage of this legislative bill is for the limited purpose of reaffirming the original legislative intent of Laws 2011, LB 215."</ref> Governor [[Pete Ricketts]] vetoed the bill; the legislature voted 34–10 to override the veto.<ref name="Duggan"/> Nebraska became the last of the 50 states to allow deferred-action recipients to obtain licenses.<ref name="Duggan"/>
===North Carolina===
North Carolina briefly suspended giving driver's licenses to DACA grantees while awaiting the state attorney general's opinion. The attorney general decided that even without formal immigration status, DACA grantees were to be granted legal presence. Subsequently, the state once again continued to give driver's licenses and allowed DACA grantees to become legal members of North Carolina.<ref>{{cite web|title=Are Individuals Granted Deferred Action under the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) Policy Eligible for State Driver's Licenses?|url=http://www.nilc.org/dacadriverslicenses.html|publisher=Immigration Law Center|accessdate=April 1, 2014}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
===Texas===
Although in-state tuition was still offered, Governor [[Rick Perry]] announced his opposition to DACA by distributing a letter to all state agencies, meant "to ensure that all Texas agencies understand that Secretary Napolitano's guidelines confer absolutely no legal status whatsoever to any illegal immigrant who qualifies for the federal 'deferred action' designation."<ref>{{cite news|last=Aguilar|first=Julian|title=Perry: "Deferred Action" Doesn't Change State Policies|url=http://www.texastribune.org/immigration-in-texas/immigration/perrydeferred-action-does-not-change-state-policie/|accessdate=October 12, 2012|newspaper=Texas Tribune|date=August 20, 2012}}</ref>
===Virginia=== In April 2014, [[Virginia Attorney General]] [[Mark Herring]] sent a letter to the director of the [[State Council of Higher Education for Virginia]] (SCHEV), the presidents of Virginia public colleges and universities, and the chancellor of the [[Virginia Community College System]] in response to inquiries from public institutions of higher education on whether DACA students were eligible for in-state tuition. The attorney general advised that under Virginia law, DACA students who met Virginia's domicile requirements were eligible for in-state tuition.<ref>[http://www.ag.virginia.gov/Media%20and%20News%20Releases/News_Releases/Herring/DACA_AG_Advice_Letter.pdf Letter from Mark R. Herring, Attorney General, Commonwealth of Virginia, to the Director of the State Council of Higher Education for Virginia, the Chancellor of the Virginia Community College System, and the presidents of Virginia public colleges and universities] (April 29, 2014).</ref><ref>Laura Vozzella & Pamela Constable, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/virginia-attorney-general-declares-dreamers-eligible-for-in-state-tuition/2014/04/29/ed594aea-cfb0-11e3-b812-0c92213941f4_story.html Virginia attorney general declares 'dreamers' eligible for in-state tuition], ''[[Washington Post]]'' (April 29, 2014).</ref>
==Rescission== While running for president, [[Donald Trump]] declared he intended to [[repeal]] DACA on "day one" of his presidency.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/politics/la-na-pol-trump-daca-20170216-story.html|title=The White House has found ways to end protection for 'Dreamers' while shielding Trump from blowback|author=Brian Bennett, Michael A. MemoliContact Reporters|date=February 16, 2017|publisher=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=February 22, 2017}}</ref>
On February 14, 2017, a CNN report on the detention of 23-year-old Daniel Ramirez Medina in [[Northwest Detention Center]],<ref name="CNN_T100_Dreamer">{{citation|title=Immigrant protected under Obama's 'Dreamer' program is detained for failure to renew her DACA application (a requirement of the Dreamers act).|date=February 15, 2017|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/02/14/politics/daniel-ramirez-medina-daca-detention/index.html|quote=The conflicting stories come amid immigrant rights attorneys' fears that President Donald Trump's administration will target the Dreamers, who were temporarily allowed to live and work in the United States after passing background checks. About 750,000 people have received permission to stay under DACA.|author=Ariane de Vogue, Madison Park, Artemis Moshtaghian and Mary Kay Mallonee|publisher=CNN|accessdate=February 15, 2017}}</ref> [[Tacoma, Washington]] following his arrest in his father's [[Des Moines, Washington]] home, observed that "The case raises questions about what it could mean" for the 750,000 Dreamers, who had "received permission to stay under DACA."<ref name="CNN_T100_Dreamer" /><ref name="Reuters_T100_Medina_ValentinesDay">{{citation|title=Exclusive: U.S. arrests Mexican immigrant in Seattle covered by Obama program|date=February 14, 2017|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-immigration-arrest-exclusiv-idUSKBN15T307|authors=Daniel Levine and Kristina Cooke|location=San Francisco|agency=Reuters|accessdate=February 14, 2017}}</ref> On March 7, 22-year-old Daniela Vargas of [[Jackson, Mississippi]], another DACA recipient, was detained by ICE, further raising speculation about President Trump's commitment to Dreamers and questioning whether immigrants who speak out against the administration's policies should fear retaliation.<ref>{{cite web|last=Schmidt |first=Samantha |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2017/03/02/ice-nabs-young-dreamer-applicant-after-she-speaks-out-at-a-news-conference/ |title=ICE nabs young 'dreamer' applicant after she speaks out at a news conference |publisher=The Washington Post |date= |accessdate=September 6, 2017}}</ref> Vargas was released from [[LaSalle Detention Center]] on March 10, 2017<ref>{{cite web|last=Sanchez |first=Ray |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/03/10/us/dreamer-daniela-vargas-ordered-released/ |title=DREAMer Daniela Vargas freed, immigration group says |publisher=CNN |date=March 10, 2017 |accessdate=September 6, 2017}}</ref> and Ramirez Medina's release followed on March 29.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-dreamer-seattle-20170328-story.html |title='Dreamer' threatened with deportation in Seattle is released after weeks of detention |publisher=LA Times |date=March 29, 2017 |accessdate=September 6, 2017}}</ref>
On June 16, 2017, the [[United States Department of Homeland Security]] announced it intended to repeal the executive order by the [[Barack Obama]] administration that expanded the DACA program, although the DACA program's overall existence would continue to be reviewed.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/06/15/trump-immigration-dreamers-status-239621|title=Trump won't alter status of current Dreamers|first=Josh|last=Gerstein|work=Politico|date=June 15, 2017|accessdate=June 15, 2017}}<br />{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/06/16/trump-daca-immigration-deportation-relief-program-239654|title=DACA still 'under review,' Trump administration says|first=Ted|last=Hesson|work=Politico|date=June 16, 2017|accessdate=June 17, 2017}}</ref>
On September 5, 2017, Attorney General [[Jeff Sessions]] announced that the program is being repealed. Sessions stated that the DACA-eligible individuals were lawbreakers who adversely impacted the wages and employment of native-born Americans.<ref name=":7">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/05/us/politics/trump-daca-dreamers-immigration.html|title=Trump Moves to End DACA and Calls on Congress to Act|last=Shear|first=Michael D.|date=September 5, 2017|work=The New York Times|access-date=September 6, 2017|last2=Davis|first2=Julie Hirschfeld|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Sessions also attributed DACA as a leading cause behind the surge in unaccompanied minors coming to the United States from Central America.<ref name=":7" /> President Trump said that "virtually all" "top legal experts" believed that DACA was unconstitutional.<ref name=":7" /> Fact-checkers have said that only a few economists believe DACA adversely affects native-born workers, that there is scant evidence that DACA caused the surge in unaccompanied minors, and that it is false that all "top legal experts" believe DACA to be unconstitutional.<ref name=":9"/><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Amuedo-Dorantes|first=Catalina|last2=Puttitanun|first2=Thitima|date=2017-12-01|title=Was DACA Responsible for the Surge in Unaccompanied Minors on the Southern Border?|journal=International Migration|language=en|volume=55|issue=6|pages=12–13|doi=10.1111/imig.12403|issn=1468-2435}}</ref>
Sessions added that implementation would be suspended for six months; DACA status and Employment Authorization Documents ("EAD") that expired during the next six months would continue to be renewed. DACA recipients with a work permit set to expire on or before March 5, 2018 would have the opportunity to apply for a two-year renewal if their application was received by USCIS by October 5, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|author=Adam Edelman|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/immigration/trump-dreamers-daca-immigration-announcement-n798686|title=Trump Ends DACA Program, No New Applications Accepted|publisher=NBC News|date=September 5, 2017|accessdate=September 6, 2017}}</ref> In a follow-up statement, Trump said "It is now time for Congress to act!"<ref name="Kopan" /> The approximately 800,000 immigrants who qualified for enrollment in DACA would become eligible for deportation by the end of those six months.<ref name=":7" /> A White House memo stated that DACA recipients should "use the time remaining on their work authorizations to prepare for and arrange their departure from the United States."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/09/05/politics/white-house-memo-daca-recipients-leave/index.html|title=Admin memo: DACA recipients should prepare for 'departure from the United States'|last1=Kopan|first1=Tai|last2=Acosta|first2=Jim|date=September 6, 2017|publisher=CNN}}</ref>
=== Reaction === [[File:DACA protest at Trump Tower (52703).jpg|thumb|right|Protesters outside Trump Tower in New York City, September 5, 2017]] [[File:DACA rally SF 20170905-8471.jpg|thumb|right|Protesters in San Francisco, September 5, 2017]] According to the ''New York Times'', "Democrats and some Republicans, business executives, college presidents and immigration activists condemned the repeal as a coldhearted and shortsighted effort that was unfair to the young immigrants and could harm the economy."<ref name=":7" /> Former President Obama condemned the repeal as "cruel" and wrote:<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/09/05/read-barack-obamas-response-to-trumps-decision-to-end-daca.html|title=Read Barack Obama's response to Trump's decision to end DACA|last=Kimball|first=Spencer|date=September 5, 2017|access-date=September 6, 2017}}</ref>
<blockquote>They were brought to this country by their parents, sometimes even as infants. They may not know a country besides ours. They may not even know a language besides English. They often have no idea they're undocumented until they apply for a job, or college, or a driver's license ... Whatever concerns or complaints Americans may have about immigration in general, we shouldn't threaten the future of this group of young people who are here through no fault of their own, who pose no threat, who are not taking away anything from the rest of us ... Kicking them out won't lower the unemployment rate, or lighten anyone's taxes, or raise anybody's wages.</blockquote>
The reaction was mixed among Republicans.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/09/05/politics/congress-reaction-daca-end-jeff-sessions-donald-trump/index.html|title=Democrats, some in GOP slam the end of DACA|authors=Daniella Diaz and Lauren Fox|publisher=CNN|access-date=September 6, 2017}}</ref> Several senior Republicans praised Trump's action, such as House Speaker [[Paul Ryan]], Senate Majority Leader [[Mitch McConnell]] and Senator [[Ron Johnson (Wisconsin politician)|Ron Johnson]], chairman of the Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee.<ref name=":16">{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/09/reacts-trump-move-scrap-daca-programme-170905201759665.html|title=US reacts to Trump's move to scrap the DACA programme|website=www.aljazeera.com|access-date=September 6, 2017}}</ref> Other Republicans, including Senators [[John McCain]] and [[Jeff Flake]], and Representative [[Ileana Ros-Lehtinen]], condemned the Trump Administration's choice to rescind the executive order.<ref name=":16" /> In a released statement Senator McCain said:<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mccain.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2017/9/statement-by-senator-john-mccain-on-president-trump-s-decision-to-end-daca|title=Statement by Senator John McCain on Trump's Decision to End DACA|last=McCain|first=United States Senator John|website=www.mccain.senate.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-11-28}}</ref>
<blockquote>I strongly believe that children who were illegally brought into this country through no fault of their own should not be forced to return to a country they do not know. The 800,000 innocent young people granted deferred action under DACA over the last several years are pursuing degrees, starting careers, and contributing to our communities in important ways. While I disagreed with President Obama's unilateral action on this issue, I believe that rescinding DACA at this time is an unacceptable reversal of the promises and opportunities that have been conferred to these individuals.</blockquote>
Organizations such as the [[American Civil Liberties Union]], [[Anti-Defamation League]], and [[U.S. Chamber of Commerce]] condemned the repeal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/lawmakers-organizations-speak-trumps-decision-end-daca/story?id=49626892|title=Lawmakers, organizations speak out after Trump's decision to end DACA|last=|first=|date=September 5, 2017|website=ABC News|access-date=September 6, 2017}}</ref> A number of religious organizations condemned the repeal, with the [[U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops]] describing it as "reprehensible". The Catholic [[University of Notre Dame]] also urged the president to not rescind DACA and announced it would stand by those affected.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Report|first1=South Bend Tribune|title=Notre Dame, other schools back DACA program|url=https://www.southbendtribune.com/news/education/notre-dame-other-schools-back-daca-program/article_06dda28c-e759-5ecd-ac32-967aafc9ff3b.html|website=South Bend Tribune|language=en}}</ref> The [[United Methodist Church]] said it was "not only unconscionable, but contrary to moral work and witness," and the [[Evangelical Lutheran Church in America|Evangelical Lutheran Church]] called on its members to "pray today for those that will suffer undue repercussions due to the end of this program."<ref name=":8">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/acts-of-faith/wp/2017/09/05/reprehensible-unconscionable-christian-leaders-react-to-trumps-decision-to-overturn-daca/|title='Reprehensible,' 'unconscionable': Christian leaders react to Trump's decision to overturn DACA|newspaper=[[Washington Post]]|access-date=September 6, 2017}}</ref> Asked about Trump's decision to rescind DACA, Pope Francis said if Trump is truly [[pro-life]], "he will understand that the family is the cradle of life and that it must be defended as a unit."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/acts-of-faith/wp/2017/09/11/pope-francis-if-trump-is-pro-life-he-should-extend-daca/|title=Pope Francis: If Trump is 'pro-life,' he should extend DACA|last=Zauzmer|first=Julie|date=2017-09-11|work=Washington Post|access-date=2017-09-11|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> [[Ralph Reed]], chairman of the [[Faith and Freedom Coalition]], endorsed Trump's repeal.<ref name=":8" />
The September 2017 announcement sparked protests in many cities including [[Washington, D.C.]], [[Chicago]], and [[Los Angeles]]. At a September 5 protest in New York outside of [[Trump Tower]], more than 30 protesters were arrested.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/arrests-made-daca-protest-york/story?id=49625957|title=DACA announcement sparks protests nationwide, dozens arrested at Trump Tower|last=Keneally|first=Meghan|date=September 6, 2017|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=September 6, 2017}}</ref> On September 19, more protesters were arrested outside Trump Tower, including Democratic congressmen [[Raúl Grijalva]] of Arizona, [[Luis Gutiérrez]] of Illinois, and [[Adriano Espaillat]] of New York.<ref name="guardian-19sep2017">{{cite news|title=Three Democratic congressmen arrested at Trump tower Daca protests|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/sep/19/trump-tower-daca-protest-congress-democrats-arrests|accessdate=September 19, 2017|newspaper=The Guardian|date=September 19, 2017}}</ref>
===Legal challenges to recission=== {{see also|New York v. Trump|Regents of University of California v. United States Department of Homeland Security}}
The rescission was challenged in court by different entities.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Harrington |first1=Ben |title=DACA Rescission: Legal Issues and Litigation Status |date=May 23, 2018 |publisher=Congressional Research Service |location=Washington, DC |url=https://fas.org/sgp/crs/homesec/LSB10136.pdf |accessdate=23 June 2018}}</ref> On September 6, 2017, fifteen states and the District of Columbia filed a lawsuit, titled ''[[New York v. Trump]]'', in the [[United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York]] seeking to stop the repeal.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kopan|first1=Tal|title=Blue states sue Trump over DACA|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/09/06/politics/daca-trump-states-lawsuits/index.html|publisher=CNN|accessdate=September 6, 2017}}</ref> A few days later, the [[Attorney General of California|California attorney general]], [[Xavier Becerra]], filed a separate lawsuit, which was joined by the states of Maine, Minnesota, and Maryland. Becerra stated that, as a quarter of the people in the DACA program live in California, he thinks that "everyone recognizes the scope and breadth of the Trump decision to terminate DACA hits hardest here."<ref name="latimes-11sep2017">{{cite news|last=McGreevy|first=Patrick|title=California politics updates: California to sue Trump administration for DACA decision|url=http://www.latimes.com/politics/essential/la-pol-ca-essential-politics-updates-california-sues-trump-administration-1505150334-htmlstory.html|accessdate=September 11, 2017|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=September 11, 2017}}</ref> Not only have state governments filed suit, but also six DREAMERs have filed suit against Trump in San Francisco.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/legal-us-usa-immigration-lawsuit/six-dreamers-sue-trump-administration-over-daca-decision-idUSKCN1BT18H|title=Six Dreamers sue Trump administration over DACA decision|date=September 18, 2017|work=Reuters|access-date=2017-11-28}}</ref> The University of California, which currently has approximately 4,000 undocumented students, has also filed a lawsuit against the Department of Homeland Security which was filed in the Northern District of California.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.universityofcalifornia.edu/press-room/university-california-sues-trump-administration-unlawful-repeal-daca-program|title=University of California sues Trump administration on unlawful repeal of DACA program|date=2017-09-11|work=University of California|access-date=2017-11-28|language=en}}</ref> Janet Napolitano, president of the UC system, called the rescission of DACA, "unconstitutional, unjust, and unlawful". In a released statement Napolitano said:
<blockquote>I am deeply troubled by President Trump's decision to effectively end the DACA program and uproot the lives of an estimated 800,000 Dreamers across the nation. This backward-thinking, far-reaching move threatens to separate families and derail the futures of some of this country's brightest young minds, thousands of whom currently attend or have graduated from the University of California.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.universityofcalifornia.edu/press-room/uc-president-napolitano-statement-decision-end-daca-program|title=UC President Napolitano denounces decision to end DACA program, calls on Congress to make protections permanent|date=2017-09-07|work=University of California|access-date=2017-11-28|language=en}}</ref></blockquote>
On December 20, 2017, the Supreme Court remanded five DACA cases originally filed in the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of California|Northern District of California]] back to the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit|Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals]]. This action stops the district court's order to deliver documents to the plaintiffs.<ref name="bb171220">{{cite news|last1=Strohr|first1=Greg|title=Supreme Court Lets Trump Team Withhold DACA Documents for Now|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-12-20/supreme-court-lets-trump-team-withhold-daca-documents-for-now|accessdate=28 December 2017|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|date=December 20, 2017}}</ref><ref name="scotus171220">{{cite web|title=IN RE UNITED STATES, ET AL.|url=https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/17pdf/17-801_6jgm.pdf|publisher=Supreme Court of the United States|accessdate=28 December 2017|date=December 20, 2017}}</ref>
On January 9, 2018, the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of California]] temporarily [[Regents of University of California v. United States Department of Homeland Security|blocked]] the rescission of the DACA program, ordering the government to renew DACA until further order of the court.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/368246-judge-blocks-trump-admin-from-ending-daca-program|title=Judge blocks Trump plan to end DACA|last=Samuels|first=Brett|date=2018-01-09|work=TheHill|access-date=2018-01-10}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2018/01/10/judge-rules-against-trump-administration-on-rescinding-daca.html|title=Judge rules against Trump administration on rescinding DACA|last=DeMarche|first=Edmund|date=2018-01-10|work=Fox News|access-date=2018-01-10|language=en-US}}</ref> On January 13, 2018, the government stated that it would immediately resume approving DACA renewal applications.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/14/us/politics/daca-renewals-requests.html|title=DACA Participants Can Again Apply for Renewal, Immigration Agency Says|last=Stevens|first=Matt|date=2018|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-01-14|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
On February 13, 2018, Judge [[Nicholas Garaufis]] of the [[U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York]] granted a preliminary injunction ordering the federal government to fully restore the DACA program, including accepting brand new applicants as well as renewals.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2018/feb/13/court-orders-full-restoration-daca-program/ |title=Court orders full restoration of DACA program |first=Stephen |last=Dinan |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=February 13, 2018 }}</ref> Moreover, as a rationale for his ruling, Garaufis said that DACA was neither unconstitutional nor in violation of the [[Administrative Procedure Act (United States)|Administrative Procedure Act]] (APA) nor the [[Immigration and Naturalization Act]] (INA).<ref>Case 1:16-cv-04756-NGG-JO [https://images.law.com/contrib/content/uploads/documents/389/21170/123113980550.pdf Document 255]. ''United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York''. February 13, 2018</ref>
On February 26, 2018, the Supreme Court declined to hear the Trump administration's request for it to review the lower court order that the administration must continue to accept DACA applications, so the Supreme Court will allow the Ninth Circuit to review the ruling.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/26/us/politics/supreme-court-trump-daca-dreamers.html|title= Justices Turn Down Trump's Appeal in 'Dreamers' Case|last=|date=2018-02-26|work=The New York Times| access-date=2018-02-26}}</ref> The effect of this ruling was to delay implementation of the rescission until at least October 2018.<ref name = SCOTUS/>
On April 24, 2018, [[John D. Bates]], a Senior United States District Judge of the [[United States District Court for the District of Columbia]], ruled that the Trump administration must resume accepting new applications for DACA but stayed his decision for 90 days to allow the Department of Homeland Security to explain why the program was being canceled.<ref>{{Cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/24/us/daca-dreamers-trump.html | title=U.S. Must Keep DACA and Accept New Applications, Federal Judge Rules| newspaper=The New York Times| date=2018-04-24| last1=Jordan| first1=Miriam}}</ref>
On August 3, 2018, Judge Bates said the Trump administration has failed to justify its proposal to end DACA; however, he stayed the ruling for 20 days to allow the Trump administration time to respond and appeal, if it chooses.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/08/03/politics/daca-ruling/index.html |title=Judge upholds ruling that DACA must be restored |date=August 3, 2018 |publisher=[[CNN|Cable News network]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cdn.cnn.com/cnn/2018/images/08/03/opinion.daca.pdf|title=Memorandum opinion|date=August 3, 2018|work=United States District Court for the District of Columbia|accessdate=4 August 2018}}</ref>
===Proposed legislative responses to the DACA repeal=== In announcing the rescission, the Trump Administration delayed implementation for six months to allow Congress to pass the DREAM Act or otherwise settle the status of Dreamers legislatively.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2017/09/10/549745978/democrats-look-to-trump-on-dream-act-after-he-puts-expiration-date-on-daca-progr|title=Democrats Look To Trump On DREAM Act After He Puts Expiration Date On DACA Program|last=Bennett|first=Geoff|date=September 10, 2017|work=NPR|accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref><ref name="NYTDREAM">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/05/us/politics/dream-act-daca-trump-congress-dreamers.html|title=After 16 Futile Years, Congress Will Try Again to Legalize 'Dreamers'|publisher=New York Times|access-date=February 13, 2018|date=September 5, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Kopan">{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/09/05/politics/daca-trump-congress/index.html|title=Trump ends DACA, but gives Congress window to save it|last=Kopan|first=Tal|publisher=CNN|date=September 5, 2017}}</ref> Multiple proposals were introduced in Congress but none passed. Proposals included: * ''[[DREAM Act]]:'' Proposed by [[Lindsey Graham|Sens. Graham]] and [[Dick Durbin|Durbin]], the DREAM Act offers protections to illegal immigrants similar to DACA, as well as offering a path to citizenship.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dream Act of 2017 Bill Summary {{!}} National Immigration Forum|url=http://immigrationforum.org/blog/dream-act-of-2017-bill-summary/?gclid=Cj0KCQiAus_QBRDgARIsAIRGNGjZUat-Y4QPd1jBq3qyphyi4Q6DxKGh9PdRqNY70w0qqRhJ72LJVuQaApt5EALw_wcB|website=National Immigration Forum|language=en|date=21 July 2017}}</ref> * ''Recognizing America's Children Act:'' Proposed by [[Carlos Curbelo|Rep. Curbelo]], RAC offers a pathway to legalization through education, military service, or work authorization. After 10 years in this program, immigrants could apply for citizenship.<ref>{{cite web|title=Recognizing America's Children Act|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/house-bill/1468|date=2017-03-22}}</ref> * ''The American Hope Act:'' Proposed by [[Luis Gutiérrez|Rep. Gutiérrez]], this act offers an expedited path to citizenship that is attainable in eight years, but the immigrant must have entered the US before the age of eighteen.<ref>{{cite web|title=The American Hope Act|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/house-bill/3591|date=2017-09-06}}</ref> * ''BRIDGE Act:'' Proposed by [[Mike Coffman|Rep. Coffman]], this bill extends the DACA program by three years, allowing more time to discuss comprehensive immigration reform.<ref>{{cite web|title=BRIDGE Act|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/house-bill/496|date=2017-09-05}}</ref> * ''[[Broader Options for Americans Act]]:'' This bill is used for immigration debate in the Senate.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Stolberg|first1=Sheryl Gay|title=Senate Begins 'Wild' Week of Debate on Immigration, Outcome Unknown|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/12/us/politics/senate-immigration-debate.html|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=15 February 2018|date=12 February 2018}}</ref>
In February 2018 the Senate considered four bills to offer legal protection to people who came to the United States illegally as children, but all four bills failed to pass.<ref name = failed>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2018/02/15/senate-set-vote-dreamer-bills-but-theres-no-clear-path-any-them/341985002/|title=Senate blocks Trump-backed immigration plan and everything else on the table|last1=Collins|first1=Eliza|last2=Sheshgreen|first2=Deirdre|date=February 15, 2018|work=USA Today|accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref> On March 5, 2018 the rescission of DACA was supposed to become effective, leaving nearly 700,000 Dreamers eligible for deportation.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2018/03/05/dreamers-daca-program-march-5-end/393280002/|title=DACA was supposed to end Monday. It didn't, but DREAMERs remain anxious.|last1=Gomez|first1=Alan|last2=Kaplan|first2=Sophie|date=March 5, 2018|work=USA Today|accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref> A [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] ruling postponed the effective date until at least October 2018. In the interim, DACA recipients remain protected and can continue to renew their protected status.<ref name = SCOTUS>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2018/02/26/what-supreme-court-ruling-means-daca-and-almost-700-000-undocumented-immigrants/372704002/|title=What the Supreme Court ruling means for DACA and almost 700,000 undocumented immigrants|last=Gomez|first=Alan|date=February 26, 2018|work=USA Today|accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref>
